awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Inference-Based Adaptation Techniques for Next Generation Jamming and Anti-Jamming Capabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
Continual advances in wireless communication technology offer additional protections against interference and jamming, but these same advances unfortunately also enable stronger attacks.   Observant attackers can achieve significant gains by incorporating knowledge of the network under attack, and jammers can consider various metrics, including attack impact, energy efficiency, and stealth.  Moreover, attackers can continually adapt parameters and behaviors to compensate for system dynamics, thwart detection, and save valuable resources. Robust wireless communication protocols that can survive such adaptive attacks require new techniques for near-real-time defensive adaptation, allowing the defenders to similarly modify their parameters in response to perceived attack impacts.

This project will involve the three primary tasks of identifying and modeling advanced inference-based jamming attacks, developing novel cross-layer network defenses to mitigate jamming attacks using similar adapatation techniques, and characterizing system-level behaviors that emerge from the interactions between multiple adapting parties. Contributions of the project will expand the existing body of knowledge in wireless network security by developing novel probabilistic, game theoretic, and control system theoretic models to better understand efficient and stealthy jamming attacks and provide a basis for future robust protocol design. Application areas in which the project work will be included are mobile commerce using NFC, home networking, medical information management, smart grid communication, and disaster response.

por.por_cntn:
Wireless communications are critically vulnerable to noise and interference, and malicious actors can leverage this feature to interrupt or prevent communication capabilities through wireless jamming. System designers are aware of the jamming threat, but most jamming attack models are fairly naïve. Because the assumed model is fairly weak, the resulting defense mechanisms cannot protect against more sophisticated jamming attacks. Our work in this project addresses these gaps with more sophisticated yet practical jamming attack and anti-jamming defense mechanisms. The primary focus of our work is on expanding attack and defense mechanisms to incorporate protocol adaptation, namely the ability for a wireless radio to modify protocol parameter and operational behaviors in real time.

The outcomes of this project included both offensive and defensive mechanisms, while considering device capabilities, operating / energy costs, and knowledge requirements. On the offensive side, we developed new capabilities for jamming attackers to use knowledge gained through observing (i.e., eavesdropping on) the opponent, allowing the attacker to gradually converge to an optimal attack or to track any dynamics of the opponent. On the defensive side, we further developed techniques that allow the radio to learn about and adapt to the impacts of an ongoing attack. We also studied the case where both the attacker and defender are trying to learn about and adapt to each other’s actions. We showed that such offense-defense interactions can be modeled and analyzed using game theory, aiming to understand how opposing “players” interact with each other in a wireless system when they have competing objectives (one to communicate, the other to prevent communication) and limited resources.

Aside from the specific research contributions, this project spawned several other projects of interest related to attacks on wireless networked control systems and building knowledge through passive observation and sensing. In addition, the outcomes of this project have been incorporated as a permanent module in the Wireless Network Security course taught at Carnegie Mellon University.
